metadata.title: A numerical and experimental assessment of a coated diesel engine powered by high-performance nano biofuel

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Energy Conversion and Management
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/enconman
A numerical and experimental assessment of a coated diesel engine powered by high-performance nano biofuel
B. Dhinesha,⁎, Y. Maria Ambrose Rajb, C. Kalaiselvanb, R. KrishnaMoorthyb
a Department of Mechanical Engineering, Mepco Schlenk Engineering College, Sivakasi, Virudhunagar, Tamil Nadu 626005, India bDepartment of Automobile Engineering, Madras Institute of Technology campus, Anna University, Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Biofuel Cerium oxide nano additive Low heat rejection Emission control Diesel engine
A B S T R A C T
The main aim of the present research is to effectively utilize the biofuel along with nano additive (Cymbopogon flexuosus biofuel with cerium oxide) powered with a coated and uncoated diesel engine. The work is further extended to study the thermal–stress analysis of the coated engine, to empathize the physical mechanism underlying the impact of coated engine on the engine behavior. In connection with this, for the present work, a novel biofuel and oxygenate additive was preferred. Biofuel- Cymbopogon flexuosus was extracted through the steam distillation technique and oxygenate additive - cerium oxide nano additive was synthesized using combustion technique. Focusing on the coating material, YSZ (Yttria-stabilized zirconia) is preferred, as it is highly used in the high-temperature application and were evaluated based on the thermal–stress analysis. From the simulation study using FEA (finite element analysis), the average temperature, and thermal stress were higher and heat flux, were noted to be lower for coated piston, confirming the substantial improvement in thermal efficiency in the experimental study. As a next step, YSZ was coated on the engine piston, valves and cylinder head by plasma spray coating technique. From the experimental assessment of test samples such as D100, B100, B25, in a uncoated engine and B25 + (A) - Cymbopogon flexuosus biofuel – 25% and diesel – 75% + 20 ppm cerium oxide nano additive) in a coated and uncoated engine. It was identified that the thermal efficiency of the engine was enhanced by 1.75% as on compared with the conventional engine for the modified fuel blend. In the emission point of view, fuel-based emissions such as hydrocarbon; carbon monoxide and smoke were reduced with a penalty of increased oxides of nitrogen emission.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The current scenario world is clambering with two main trouble such us fossil fuel demand and environmental emission scarcity [1]. In this regard, a better way to overcome this crisis is to find an alternate energy for the petroleum-based fuels [2]. Among the non-renewable fuel competitors, biofuel is leading its rivals to substitute fossil fuels in the transportation sector for cross over the fuel and emission scarcity. Recent day’s biofuel has been earning more attention owing to their cunning characteristics namely renewability in nature and greener emission [3]. Many numbers of positive points listed when biofuel consider as an alternate transport fuel namely mass availability, ecofriendly, renewable, biodegradable and sustainability [4].
In particular, researchers are concentrating on the biofuel derived from the agricultural fermentation, biological waste regeneration, and biomass especially. It can be used in a conventional diesel engine without any major modification that emits minimal toxic emission except for nitrogen oxide [5]. Biofuels are also alcohols, which need
certain engine modification for its optimal running condition in the diesel engine. In the circumstance of nonrenewable petroleum-based fuel scarcity, all around the world, a number of research works have been done with vegetable oil, biomass, animal fats, waste cooking oil and biofuel [6]. Many of the researchers proved using biofuel in CI (Compression Ignition) engine resulted in reduced efficiency due to minimal calorific value caused by lower hydrogen and availability of the oxygen in biofuel. Interestingly, exhaust emission was reduced because of oxygen content in biofuel compared with diesel fuel [7]. Researcher Dhinesh et al performed a study on a naturally aspired diesel engine using Cymbopogon flexuous biofuel. From their observation, they concluded that B20 blend had higher efficiency and better fuel economy than other blend but it lies lower than diesel fuel [8]. Sanjid et al. analyzed the impact of palm, mustard, waste cooking oil and Calophyllum inophyllum on compression ignition engine. From their observation, they concluded that mustard oil biofuel resulted in reducing the oxide of nitrogen than another biofuel [9]. Researcher Kezrane Cheikh et al. tested their conventional engine powered with the blend
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.enconman.2018.06.039 Received 3 February 2018; Received in revised form 10 June 2018; Accepted 11 June 2018
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: dhineshbala91@gmail.com (B. Dhinesh).
Energy Conversion and Management 171 (2018) 815–824
0196-8904/ © 2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
T
of waste cooking oil and they report that a 100% wco blend earned higher in-cylinder pressure than diesel fuel owing to shortened the ignition delay for the addition of biodiesel [10]. It was concluded that the direct usage of biodiesel in conventional engine, has certain negative impact such us higher fuel consumption, lower thermal efficiency, less cloud and pour point and higher nitrogen oxide to overcome this negative points the easiest way is the adulteration of fuel by adding additives such us oxygenated additives, anti-oxygenated additive and nano additives [11].
It is identified that the usage of the oxygenated additives affirmed to ignite the fuel more expeditiously and diminish engine exhaust pollution drastically [12]. The addition of Butylated hydroxytoluene and nbutanol antioxidant additive with waste cooking oil diminished the NOx emissions, because the antioxidant additive has the capability to quench the free radicals throughout combustion phase by Senthur Prabu [13]. Vijayakumar Chandrasekaran et al. reported that on experimenting copper oxide as a nano additive [50 ppm] with B20 of Mahua oil in a diesel engine would reduce the incomplete combustion products, and enhance the cold start and thermal efficiency. Nevertheless, to employ the copper oxide nano additive in fossil fuel engine may cause negative consequences, enhanced the rate of fuel consumption and nitrogen oxides emission was discovered [14]. It was identified that the engine resulted in higher power output on using the anti-oxidant [15], metal-based fuel born additives [16] namely iron, copper, cerium, and platinum, and it encourages the fully complete combustion [17].
The majority of the investigator have proved that thermal insulation can reduce the heat transfer rate and improve the thermal efficiency and the heat availability in the engine exhaust [18]. The low heat rejection engine makes use of various ceramic coatings materials such as Mullite, TiO2, Al2O3, MgO–ZrO2, YSZ and etc. It can be coated on the piston, cylinder parts and valves. Among which the partially stabilized zirconia (6–9% yttria stabilized Zirconia) was mostly used especially for Thermal Barrier Coating (TBC) material due to its demonstrated greater performance and its ability to withstand high temperature [19]. The researcher Bahattin İşcan et al., studied the influences of low heat rejection concept using waste vegetable oil on compression ignition diesel engine. From the observation, they found that higher power and torque of the engine was obtained with the simultaneous reduction of the engine emission except for NOx emission [20]. On the experimental investigation with the fly ash-coated low heat, rejection engine powered by rice bran methyl ester and Pongamia methyl ester and its blend 20% by volume basis. The test result exhibited lower fuel economy and higher power out and as well as improved the engine exhaust except for oxide of nitrogen reported by Mohamed Musthafa [21]. Low Heat Rejection (LHR) engines had one added advantage it aided to effectively utilize the lower cetane fuel than uncoated engine due to higher temperature accumulate inside the combustion chamber because of thermal insulation [22]. Since the temperature in the combustion chamber is higher in the LHR engines than that of uncoated engines, it is possible to use lower cetane number fuels in LHR engine especially biofuel in an
effective manner [23]. All the researchers corresponded with one important point, that the NOx emission of the LHR lies higher for all the fuels especially for the biodiesels and vegetable oils owing to heat insulation [24]. The test was carried out with low heat rejection engine the materials of 88% ZrO2, 4% MgO and 8% Al2O3 coated for 400 µm on piston bowl, cylinder head and valves. Selman Aydin, studied the LHR engine performance, combustion and emission profile from their observation they concluded that partial improvement in fuel economy, brake thermal efficiency, CO, HC and smoke emission [25]. On analyzing the influence of thermal insulation in a conventional engine and they reported that diminution in fuel consumption with a slender increase in thermal efficiency is possible with the LHR [26]. Even if, in adverse, some of them reported no melioration in the efficiency [33].
At the end of the detailed discussion carried out, it was identified that plant-based biofuel with lower viscosity stays as a potential source for a substitute for diesel fuel. Hence, the Cymbopogon flexuosus a plant-based renewable biofuel has been preferred for this present research work. In this regard, as the first phase of research, the test fuel such as raw biofuel, 25% blend of biofuel was prepared. Further, a novel oxygenated additive, cerium oxide was synthesized and mixed with the 25% blend of the biofuel. Prior to the handle the engine modification of coating the engine with low heat rejection material of YSZ (Yttria-stabilized zirconia) a finite elemental analysis study was carried out using ABAQUS. For the study, the engine piston was modeled using CATIA, a 3D modeling tool, and the temperature distribution, heat flux and thermal stress in YSZ coated piston and conventional aluminum alloy piston was investigated. As the second the phase of the research work, the engine was coated with the YSZ (Yttria-stabilized zirconia) material, and the engine behavior with the test fuels considered was studied.

sections.heading: 2.1. Test fuel preparation
sections.text:
To handle the fast fossil fuel depletion, the author has preferred Cymbopogon flexuosus biofuel as an alternative energy source for this current research work. Cymbopogon flexuosus, a plant-based biofuel highly available in India and Srilanka. The biofuel is exacted from the stacks of the plant through steam distillation technique. The detailed oil extraction technique and the Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) results have been mentioned in the previous research work of the author by himself [11]. The viscosity of the oil lies closer to the diesel fuel, which is the eye-catching property of this novel biofuel. To begin with, the raw oil B100 (Cymbopogon flexuosus 100%) and B25 (Cymbopogon flexuosus 25% and diesel fuel 75%) were prepared on a volume basis for the experimental analysis. Later, the cerium oxide nano additive [31,36] was synthesized and characterized for the present research work. The detailed description on the synthesized and characterized has been already discussed in the author previous research work by himself [27]. The next test fuel of considered is B25 +
Nomenclature
YSZ Yttria-stabilized zirconia FEA Finite Element Analysis CI Compression Ignition TBC Thermal Barrier Coating LHR Low Heat Rejection BP Brake Power BTE Brake Thermal Efficiency BSEC Brake Specific Energy Consumption CA Crank Angle CO Carbon Monoxide
HC Hydrocarbon NOx Oxides of Nitrogen Ppm Parts per million TDC Top dead Centre ASTM American Society for Testing and Materials RPM Rotation per minute FTIR Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy HSU Hartridge Smoke Unit FEA Finite Elemental Analysis PSZ Partially Stabilized Zirconia DOF Degree of Freedom
(A) (Cymbopogon flexuosus 25% and diesel fuel 75%+20 ppm of cerium oxide nano additive). It was prepared by mixing 1 L of B25 with 20mg of cerium oxide nano additive. To form a homogenous mixture, the blend was mixed in ultrasonicator equipment [35]. The detailed fuel specification of the considered test samples is listed out in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Coating material
sections.text: YSZ has opted as the thermal barrier coated material, for the present research work, the reason behind the selection of this material is due to its higher coefficient of thermal expansion and lower thermal conductivity and high melting point 2800 °C. The composition of the YSZ is eight-mole percentage of Yttria (Y2O3) and remaining mole percentage of fully stabilized Zirconia (ZrO2). The engine components such as piston head, inlet and exhaust value base surface, and the cylinder head region were coated by YSZ through plasma spray coating technique. The coating substrate material of the piston, value and the cylinder head are subjected to two major processes namely such as grit blasting, and ultrasonic cleaning process respectively. In the grit blasting process the surface roughness of the material treated until it, roughness (Ra) reaches 4. Further, to achieve better binding, the substrate material is ultrasonically cleaned by glycol. At the end of this process, after YSZ material is coated over the regions preferred using air plasma spray technique. Yttria Stabilized Zirconia (YSZ) is sprayed in powder form, on the piston, value and the cylinder head and the piston crown of a nominal thickness. Fig. 1. Represents the engine coated with YSZ material.

sections.heading: 2.3. Experimental setup and uncertainty analysis
sections.text:
The present research work was carried out in a single cylinder diesel fuel direct injection research engine. The research engine make is of Kirloskar, whose engine output shaft is coupled with eddy current dynamometer made by Benz. The engine has the capability to produce a maximum power output of 5.2 kW for a fixed speed of 1500 rpm. The manufacturer-specified operating conditions such as injection pressure of 200 bar, injection timing of 23° bTDC were kept idle throughout the research work. To begin with, the test was intimated with the diesel fuel, for five different load conditions of 0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100% and the base readings were observed [35]. Next, the engine was powered with B100, B25, and B25 + (A) in the uncoated engine, whose detailed specification is displayed in Fig. 2 and listed out in Table 2. Finally, the B25 + (A), is powered by the coated research engine and represented as B25 + (A) + (C) and its engine behavior was studied. The performance characteristics such as brake thermal efficiency and brake specific energy consumption were determined by varying the load and monitoring the fuel quantity required to propel the engine at constant speed. The fuel quantity was measured using the stopwatch and burette, where to increase the accuracy level, the measurements were carried out three times and only their average values were considered for the calculation. The combustion characteristics such as incylinder pressure and heat release rate were determined using the AVL combustion analyzer.
The in-cylinder is deveined by observing the pressure inside the combustion chamber through pressure transducer, and its respective crank angle is noted down through a crank angle encoder fitted to the flywheel. The emission parameters are determined using two equipment is namely, AVL 444 di-gas analyzer, and AVL 437 smoke meter [34]. The emission such as HC in ppm, CO in % of volume and NOx in ppm are measured using the AVL 444 di-gas analyzer, while the smoke opacity in Hartridge Smoke Unit (HSU) is measured through AVL 437 smoke meter. The engine was warmed up priorly before each test conditions, and the fuel in the tank and the flow tubes are drained completely before any fuel modification is performed. A keen cautioned was maintained on the cooling water and the lubricating oil throughout the study and the experimental analysis was performed in the steady
state condition. The uncertainty analysis is an important analysis that has to been carried out to reduce the error in the experimental analysis, as the experimental study is incorporated with a various measuring instrument with a different manufacturer, there is a possibility to occur random errors [28]. In addition, the environmental condition, operating condition and way of observation of each individual paved the way for the uncertainty errors. Using the Holman [32] methodology on uncertainty analysis was determined analytically [29]. The total uncertainty of the experiment performed was found to be 2.03% is presented in Table 3, which is agreeing well with the earlier results of Vedharaj et al. [26].

sections.heading: 3. Numerical 3D modeling of the diesel engine piston using FEA
sections.text: For this current study, CATIA, a 3D modeling tool is used for geometric solid modeling of the engine piston. Based on the existing single cylinder diesel engine, piston specification the piston was modeled, which has a bore of 87.5mm and stroke of 110mm. The designed model is saved as the user-friendly file type of CAT Part file and imported to ABAQUS for conducting finite element analysis. ABAQUS is a typical tool used in most of the industrial sectors for analyzing automobile and aerospace components. It renders a good collection multiphysics analysis, which can have been coupled with one or more to solve the engineering problems. In this study, the two different multiphysics has been coupled namely static structural, and static thermal analysis on the piston has been performed. Since the stress/displacement solution is dependent on a temperature field but there is no inverse dependency, a sequentially coupled thermal-stress analysis is performed. The engine is coated with the selected low heat rejection materials over the piston head, inlet and exhaust valves, and cylinder. The improvement in the thermal efficiency can be assured with the manifestation of rejection of heat/temperature and heat flux in any one coated engine region. For this present study, the Finite Elemental Analysis (FEA) is carried out on the piston. To begin within the preprocessing stage, the piston solid geometry meshes with the tetrahedral solid element (DC3D10), and a converge test was performed. Table 4 represents the results of the converge test, it states that the by considering the maximum temperature as an appropriate parameter, the maximum number of elements is determined. For this present study, the results were converged at 530.6 °C for 378,014 elements, where the percentage difference lies within the range of 0.4%. The meshed piston geometry with a higher order element is depicted in Fig. 3. The author has performed the analysis with the existing aluminum material, and with YSZ (Yttrium Stabilized Zirconia). The detailed material properties for the study has been displayed in Table 5 where the material properties of the aluminum literature [26] and YSZ were obtained from the literature survey carried [26].

sections.heading: 3.1. Boundary conditions
sections.text:
Fig. 4 brings out the boundary condition applied for the present study, it is represented as two sectors namely (a) boundary condition for thermal analysis, (b) boundary condition for structural analysis. The thermal analysis dealt with the temperature of the medium and its heat
transfer coefficient. The medium considered for the present study are the piston head, the lateral surface of the piston and piston skirt along with gudgeon pin. Based on the keen literature, it was identified that the temperature and heat transfer coefficient for the piston head is 600 °C, the average temperature during the suction, compression, combustion and exhaust process) and 8.0 mW/mm2 K, for lateral surface of the piston is 300 °C and 2.30mW/mm2 K. whereas for the piston skirt along with gudgeon pin, it is 60 °C and 0.85mW/mm2 K. Focusing on the structural analysis, literally it was studied that the for the static load the maximum in-cylinder pressure of 80 bar at maximum loading condition, was applied on the top of the piston after restraining the
gudgeon pin area.

sections.heading: 3.2. Thermal–stress analysis
sections.text: The results of both the thermal and static (stress) analysis are interconnected as in sequentially coupled analysis. At firstly, thermal analysis was conducted by applying the above stated thermal boundary condition and the results of the thermal analysis that is temperature distribution are obtained. Secondly, static analysis is performed in which temperature distribution from the thermal analysis is given as an input along with above-said combustion pressure. The result in the static analysis has combined effect of both thermal and static analysis as both analyses are sequentially coupled. Nodes must be same for thermal and static analysis to perform sequentially coupled analysis and problem are solved subsequently. Finally, in the post-processing stage, the heat flux, temperature distribution and the thermal stress images are catered for the aluminum and YSZ coated piston.

sections.heading: 3.3. Thermal–stress analysis of piston using FEA
sections.text:
From a keen examination of Fig. 5, the temperature distribution using FEA on the piston with uncoated (aluminum) and coated (YSZ)
material, it is concluded that the heat transfer to the surrounding is minimum in the case of YSZ coated material. YSZ coated piston, resulting in un-uniformed temperature distribution throughout the piston profile, which can be attributed as the result of the lower thermal conductivity of the material considered of 0.8W/Mk. The coated piston resulted in the higher temperature range of 530.6 °C, as compared with the uncoated piston range of 458.6 °C. The heat fluxes variation of the coated piston and uncoated piston has been depicted in Fig. 6. As compared with the uncoated piston, the coated piston heat flux has
been reduced substantially as the result of the insulation material heat trapping capability. Similar to the earlier finding of Vedharaj et al. [26] from his experimental and theoretical analysis stated that the coated engine with Partially Stabilized Zirconia (PSZ) results in higher temperature distribution and reduced heat flux capability. That is the case, for the present study of the piston coated with YSZ, resulted in higher temperature distribution and lower heat flux as on compared with the uncoated piston. Thus it can be concluded that, based on the simulation results, it can be assured that the experimental study will result in the brake thermal efficiency will be an improvement and a reduced fuel consumption level. In the coating of the piston, the binding of the two materials plays a key role. The thermal expansion of the base material and the coated material different are different to each other. In general, in order to get a better binding of two materials at a higher temperature, the difference between the thermal expansion of the two materials must stay low. If it is too higher, then it leads to paving way for delamination of the coated material or propagation of cracks to nullify the effect of the coating. As a result of the optimum thermal expansion of the YSZ, the durability of the coating has been enhanced. When yttrium stabilized zirconia is coated with the aluminum piston, the different thermal expansion coefficient of coating material and base material may cause excess stress due to the combustion temperature. So the stress levels are checked for Yttrium stabilized Zirconia (YSZ) coated piston for both combustion temperature and combustion pressure loads. The maximum von Mises stress is 324.8 MPa in Fig. 7, which is under the durable limit.

sections.heading: 4.1. Performance characteristics
sections.text:
Fig. 8 represents the brake thermal efficiency of the test fuel with and without coated engine. To begin the study was performed with the diesel fuel. It was identified that the diesel fuel resulted in a thermal efficiency of 31.49%. It was attributed due to the enhanced fuel properties and the optimum viscousness of the diesel fuel. Next to that, the study was performed with Cymbopogon flexuosus biofuel (B100), it was noted that at full load condition, the performance observed was only 25.37%. It can be reasoned out as the result of the thermophysical properties of the biofuel, where the density, viscosity stays higher and the calorific value stays lower as on compared with the diesel fuel [30]. Hence, to enhance the performance of the biofuel, it was blended with diesel fuel by 25% of the blends (B25) and later on, cerium oxide nano additive at 20 ppm was also added to the blend (B25 + (A)) and the test was carried out. From the experimental analysis, it was identified that blended fuel resulted in 28.62% and the blended fuel with the additive
resulted in 29.98%. It can be ascribed due to the enhanced in fuel properties such as an increase in calorific value and the reduced viscousness of the fuel as on blending diesel with the biofuel. The reason for the enhanced performance for the additive-based blend can be stated due to the oxygen vacancy capability of the additive that enhanced the combustion efficiency. On introducing the coated piston along the modified fuel, it was observed that the performance, further enhanced to 30.51%. It may be reasoned out as the reason of retainment of heat inside the combustion zone by coating the engine with YSZ material that reduced the loss of heat from the combustion zone to the surrounding. The lower thermal conductivity of the material, helped to accumulate the heat inside the combustion zone, which in turn increased the in-cylinder temperature and thermal efficiency accordingly. Fig. 9 represents the brake specific energy consumption profile of the test fuel considered with and without coated engine. As like to the thermal efficiency profile, the diesel fuel resulted in the least fuel consumption level. Whereas B100, turned as a disaster in the fuel consumption level, due to the lower calorific value of 16.14% and higher viscosity of the fuel of 58.62%. To maintain the same engine power output level, B100 has to compensate on the fuel consumption level by injecting more quantity of fuel. For (B25) and (B25 + (A), the brake specific energy consumption profile further gets stepped down as the result of the enhanced fuel properties. Concentrating on the coated engine, because of the heat-trapping capability of the YSZ material, the fuel consumption level further stepped down and lied closer to the diesel profile, which is evident with the BSEC profile.

sections.heading: 4.2. Combustion characteristics
sections.text:
Fig. 10 bring out the in-cylinder pressure curve for the diesel engine operated with the Cymbopogon flexuosus biofuel blend with nano additive on a coated and uncoated engine. The peak pressure obtained for the diesel fuel at full load condition is of 58.62 bar. On the diesel engine operation with the B100, the peak pressure obtained is of 58.21 bar, the occurrence of the result can be justified due to the superior cetane number capability, and oxygen availability of the biofuel. As on blending the diesel with the biofuel the peak pressure increased marginally to 60.67 bar, while along with the additive the pressure observed was 67.98 bar. The result obtained can be attributed as the result of the participation of nanoparticles in the combustion process that enhances the surface area and oxygen availability. Focusing on the coated piston, the trapped heat from the previous cycle, aided to enhance the in-cylinder pressure and temperature by burning this mixture completely. In addition, the peak pressure obtained for the coated engine turned up to 68.93 bar. Similar to the peak pressure occurrence, the heat release rate too followed the same order. The least heat release
was obtained for diesel fuel, and the maximum was B25 + (A) +(C), as it is well adverse that higher the pressure formation higher the heat release rate occurrence. The Fig. 11 aggress well with the earlier finding. As like all biofuel, the biofuel-based test resulted had a domination profile on the later stage of combustion.

sections.heading: 4.3. Emission characteristics
sections.text:
Fig. 12 discloses the hydrocarbon emission profile for the diesel engine operated with the Cymbopogon flexuosus biofuel blend with nano additive on a coated and uncoated engine. It is evident from the graph that the diesel fuel emission varies from 35 ppm to 67 ppm for no load to the full load condition. The HC emission increase gradually irrespective of the test condition as the load gets steeper; it may be, as the quantity of fuel engine gets higher to maintain the same engine speed as the load gets higher. B100 results in HC emission ranges from 33 ppm to 60 ppm. The drop in emission formation as compared with the diesel fuel is the presence of oxygen molecule in the biofuel. In addition, the emission formation was reduced for B25 ranges from 31 ppm to 59 ppm and B25+ (A) ranges from 29 ppm to 55 ppm. The occurrence of result can be stated due to the availability of the oxygen mole in the B25 blend. Where for the additive-based blend, the emission stepped down further, owing to the oxygen vacancy capability of the cerium oxide, which acts as an oxidizing agent. Finally, on the operating of the coated engine with the modified fuel blend, the emission observed was 27 ppm to 53 ppm. The drastic emission reduction with the coated engine can be stated as the result of the accumulation of the heat inside the combustion zone and the combined effect of the oxygenated additive and fuel.
Fig. 13 reveals the carbon monoxide emission results for the diesel engine operated with the Cymbopogon flexuosus biofuel blend with nano additive on a coated and uncoated engine. Carbon monoxide emission occurs mainly due to fuel richness and unavailability of the oxygen in the combustion zone. In accordance with this, the diesel fuel resulted in higher CO emission ranges from 0.09 to 0.2% of volume. Which can be stated as the result of the unavailability of the oxygen in the combustion zone. Irrespective of the test fuels, at full load condition the CO emission is higher, as more quantity if fuel is injected in the combustion zone to operate the engine in high load a constant speed condition, this results in fuel rich zone inside the combustion zone. For B100, B25 and B25+ (A), the emission formation ranges from 0.062 to 0.177, 0.064 to 0.1673, and 0.061 to 0.147% of volume of CO emission respectively. The reason for the higher emission formation for the B100, in spite of the oxygen availability is the higher viscousness of the biofuel. Whereas the drop in emission for the B25 was identified as the result of, the reduced viscosity and optimum heating value of the fuel.
B25+ (A) resulted in the least emission formation because of the pooled effect of the biofuel blend and oxidizing capability of the cerium oxide. On introducing the Coated engine, the CO emission further stepped down, as the heat entrapped inside combustion zone enhanced the evaporation and oxidation of B25+(A), and resulted in 0.058 to 0.14% of the volume of CO emission.
Fig. 14 represents the oxides of nitrogen emission variation of the
diesel engine powered by the various test fuels in coated and uncoated engine. Diesel fuel emits lower oxides of nitrogen emission as compared with the remaining test fuel, it is also well agreeing with the pressure and heat release curve obtained. The reason for that lower emission occurrence is due to the variation in the temperature and the availability of the oxygen inside the combustion zone for the diesel fuel, whose ranges varies from 84 ppm to 689 ppm. For the raw biofuel B100, the emission had a marginal fluctuation of 90–712 ppm, which can be attributed due to the availability of oxygen molecule in the biofuel. On handling fuel modification such as blending of biofuel with diesel fuel and introducing nano additive to blend, the emission ranges increased for B25 by 92–723 ppm, and minimally reduced for B25 + (A) by 87–702 ppm. The reason for the drop in emission on introducing the nano additive to the fuel is the reducing agent capability of the cerium oxide nano additive. Concentrating on the coated engine, the emission enhanced marginally to 94–720 ppm, as the heat trapped inside the combustion zone led the key role increase the in-cylinder temperature thereby the oxides of nitrogen emission.
Fig. 15 exposes the smoke opacity variation of the diesel engine operated with the Cymbopogon flexuosus biofuel blend with nano additive on a coated and uncoated engine. Diesel engine emitted higher smoke emission of 14.7–75 HSU as compared with the remaining test sample, and the emission gets increased as the load gets increased. It may be stated due to the insufficient oxidation effect of soot particle because of the absence of oxygen molecule in the diesel fuel. While the remaining oxygenated test samples resulted in lower smoke emission as compared with the diesel fuel, B100, B25 resulted in 13–64.3 ppm,
13.8–63 ppm respectively. It may be ascribed as the result of the availability of the oxygen molecule in the fuel, and the enhance evaporation rate because of reduced viscosity and increased cetane number. As introducing the nano additive to the biofuel blend, the smoke emission dropped down to 13–59 ppm as a result of the enhanced calorific value and reduced viscosity. The increased surface area capability of the Nano additive also played a key role in the emission reduction occurrence. For the coated engine, the smoke emission obtained was 12.3–56 ppm, the heat trapped inside in the combustion zone, aided to promote of the oxidation of soot reaction and reduced the fuel rich zone formation.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: To handle the fast fossil fuel depletion, the researcher has identified a plant-based novel renewable biofuel Cymbopogon flexuosus. The raw oil was extracted by the steam distillation technique, and was blended with diesel fuel and cerium oxide nano additive with 20 ppm. The study was carried out in two phases, in phase one, the finite elemental analysis was carried out for the coated and uncoated engine using aluminum and YSZ material. From the results, it was concluded that, increased temperature distribution, and reduced heat flux paved the way for increased thermal efficiency and reduced fuel consumption. The study was performed on the uncoated diesel engine with D100, B100, B25, and B25 + (A). From the analysis it was concluded that the B25 + (A) resulted in enhanced performance and effective emission reduction and herewith named as high-performance biofuel. Finally, the high-performance biofuel was operated in the coated diesel engine and compared with the uncoated engine, resulting in 1.75% of increased thermal efficiency as a result of reduced heat flux over the piston crown. The combustion parameters such as in-cylinder pressure and heat release rate, also stepped up as the result of the accumulation of heat inside the combustion chamber. Where the fuel-based emission such as HC, CO, and Smoke opacity was turned down by 3.63%, 4.75%, and 5.05% respectively due to the entrapment of the heat inside the combustion zone. While oxides of nitrogen were increased minimally. On, the whole it was resolved that the high-performance biofuel in the coated diesel engine resulted in superior performance characteristics and effective tailpipe emission reduction.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: The investigators would also like to thank the faculty of the Department of Automobile Engineering, Anna University, MIT Campus, Chennai, for their generous support in accomplishing the task.

referenceMentions.context: The current scenario world is clambering with two main trouble such us fossil fuel demand and environmental emission scarcity [1].
In this regard, a better way to overcome this crisis is to find an alternate energy for the petroleum-based fuels [2].
Recent day’s biofuel has been earning more attention owing to their cunning characteristics namely renewability in nature and greener emission [3].
friendly, renewable, biodegradable and sustainability [4].
It can be used in a conventional diesel engine without any major modification that emits minimal toxic emission except for nitrogen oxide [5].

In the circumstance of nonrenewable petroleum-based fuel scarcity, all around the world, a number of research works have been done with vegetable oil, biomass, animal fats, waste cooking oil and biofuel [6].
Interestingly, exhaust emission was reduced because of oxygen content in biofuel compared with diesel fuel [7].
From their observation, they concluded that B20 blend had higher efficiency and better fuel economy than other blend but it lies lower than diesel fuel [8].
observation, they concluded that mustard oil biofuel resulted in reducing the oxide of nitrogen than another biofuel [9].
of waste cooking oil and they report that a 100% wco blend earned higher in-cylinder pressure than diesel fuel owing to shortened the ignition delay for the addition of biodiesel [10].

It was concluded that the direct usage of biodiesel in conventional engine, has certain negative impact such us higher fuel consumption, lower thermal efficiency, less cloud and pour point and higher nitrogen oxide to overcome this negative points the easiest way is the adulteration of fuel by adding additives such us oxygenated additives, anti-oxygenated additive and nano additives [11].
It is identified that the usage of the oxygenated additives affirmed to ignite the fuel more expeditiously and diminish engine exhaust pollution drastically [12].

The addition of Butylated hydroxytoluene and nbutanol antioxidant additive with waste cooking oil diminished the NOx emissions, because the antioxidant additive has the capability to quench the free radicals throughout combustion phase by Senthur Prabu [13].
Nevertheless, to employ the copper oxide nano additive in fossil fuel engine may cause negative consequences, enhanced the rate of fuel consumption and nitrogen oxides emission was discovered [14].

It was identified that the engine resulted in higher power output on using the anti-oxidant [15], metal-based fuel born additives [16] namely iron, copper, cerium, and platinum, and it encourages the fully complete combustion [17].

The majority of the investigator have proved that thermal insulation can reduce the heat transfer rate and improve the thermal efficiency and the heat availability in the engine exhaust [18].

Among which the partially stabilized zirconia (6–9% yttria stabilized Zirconia) was mostly used especially for Thermal Barrier Coating (TBC) material due to its demonstrated greater performance and its ability to withstand high temperature [19].
From the observation, they found that higher power and torque of the engine was obtained with the simultaneous reduction of the engine emission except for NOx emission [20].
The test result exhibited lower fuel economy and higher power out and as well as improved the engine exhaust except for oxide of nitrogen reported by Mohamed Musthafa [21].
utilize the lower cetane fuel than uncoated engine due to higher temperature accumulate inside the combustion chamber because of thermal insulation [22].

Since the temperature in the combustion chamber is higher in the LHR engines than that of uncoated engines, it is possible to use lower cetane number fuels in LHR engine especially biofuel in an effective manner [23].

All the researchers corresponded with one important point, that the NOx emission of the LHR lies higher for all the fuels especially for the biodiesels and vegetable oils owing to heat insulation [24].

Selman Aydin, studied the LHR engine performance, combustion and emission profile from their observation they concluded that partial improvement in fuel economy, brake thermal efficiency, CO, HC and smoke emission [25].

On analyzing the influence of thermal insulation in a conventional engine and they reported that diminution in fuel consumption with a slender increase in thermal efficiency is possible with the LHR [26].

metadata.abstractText: The main aim of the present research is to effectively utilize the biofuel along with nano additive (Cymbopogon flexuosus biofuel with cerium oxide) powered with a coated and uncoated diesel engine. The work is further extended to study the thermal–stress analysis of the coated engine, to empathize the physical mechanism underlying the impact of coated engine on the engine behavior. In connection with this, for the present work, a novel biofuel and oxygenate additive was preferred. BiofuelCymbopogon flexuosus was extracted through the steam distillation technique and oxygenate additive cerium oxide nano additive was synthesized using combustion technique. Focusing on the coating material, YSZ (Yttria-stabilized zirconia) is preferred, as it is highly used in the high-temperature application and were evaluated based on the thermal–stress analysis. From the simulation study using FEA (finite element analysis), the average temperature, and thermal stress were higher and heat flux, were noted to be lower for coated piston, confirming the substantial improvement in thermal efficiency in the experimental study. As a next step, YSZ was coated on the engine piston, valves and cylinder head by plasma spray coating technique. From the experimental assessment of test samples such as D100, B100, B25, in a uncoated engine and B25 + (A) Cymbopogon flexuosus biofuel – 25% and diesel – 75% + 20 ppm cerium oxide nano additive) in a coated and uncoated engine. It was identified that the thermal efficiency of the engine was enhanced by 1.75% as on compared with the conventional engine for the modified fuel blend. In the emission point of view, fuel-based emissions such as hydrocarbon; carbon monoxide and smoke were reduced with a penalty of increased oxides of nitrogen emission.
